item.title: cos²(θ/2) = (1 + cos(θ))/2
item.description:
Let’s prove the identity step by step.

\[ \cos^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) = \frac{1 + \cos\theta}{2} \]

Step 1: Start with the Double-Angle Identity

\[ \cos(2\alpha) = 2\cos^2\alpha - 1 \]\[ \cos(2 \times \frac{\theta}{2}) = 2\cos^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) - 1 \]

Step 2: Simplify the Left Side

\[ \cos\theta = 2\cos^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) - 1 \]

Step 3: Isolate \( \cos^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) \)

\[ \cos\theta + 1 = 2\cos^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) \]\[ \cos^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) = \frac{1 + \cos\theta}{2} \]

Conclusion:

\[ \cos^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) = \frac{1 + \cos\theta}{2} \]

This identity is useful in various applications of trigonometry, particularly when dealing with half-angle formulas.

item.title: sin²(θ/2) = (1 - cos(θ))/2
item.description:
Step-by-Step Proof

\[ \sin^{2}\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) = \frac{1 - \cos(\theta)}{2} \]

Step 1: Recall the Double-Angle Identity for Cosine

\[ \cos(2\alpha) = 1 - 2\sin^{2}(\alpha) \]\[ \cos(2\alpha) = 2\cos^{2}(\alpha) - 1 \]

Step 2: Apply the Double-Angle Identity to \(\theta\) and \(2\theta/2\)

\[ \alpha = \frac{\theta}{2} \]

Then, \(2\alpha = \theta\). Substituting into the double-angle identity:

\[ \cos(\theta) = 1 - 2\sin^{2}\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) \]

Step 3: Solve for \( \sin^{2}\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) \)

\[ \cos(\theta) = 1 - 2\sin^{2}\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) \]\[ \cos(\theta) - 1 = -2\sin^{2}\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) \]\[ 1 - \cos(\theta) = 2\sin^{2}\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) \]

Step 4: Divide Both Sides by 2

item.title: tan²(θ/2) = (1 - cos(θ))/(1 + cos(θ))
item.description:
To prove the identity \(\tan^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) = \frac{1 - \cos\theta}{1 + \cos\theta}\), we can use the half-angle formulas for sine and cosine. Here’s a step-by-step explanation:

  1. \[ \tan\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) = \frac{\sin\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)}{\cos\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)} \]\[ \tan^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) = \left(\frac{\sin\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)}{\cos\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)}\right)^2 = \frac{\sin^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)}{\cos^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)} \]

  2. Use the half-angle identities for sine and cosine:

    • For sine: \[ \sin\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) = \sqrt{\frac{1 - \cos\theta}{2}} \]
    • For cosine: \[ \cos\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) = \sqrt{\frac{1 + \cos\theta}{2}} \]
  3. \[ \sin^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) = \frac{1 - \cos\theta}{2} \]\[ \cos^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) = \frac{1 + \cos\theta}{2} \]
  4. \[ \tan^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) = \frac{\frac{1 - \cos\theta}{2}}{\frac{1 + \cos\theta}{2}} \]
  5. \[ \tan^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) = \frac{1 - \cos\theta}{1 + \cos\theta} \]

This completes the proof that \(\tan^2\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)\) equals \(\frac{1 - \cos\theta}{1 + \cos\theta}\).
